title: Target set selection with maximum activation time

sections.preliminaries:
Graphs. We refer the reader toÂ  for basic background on graph theory, and recall here only some useful definitions. We consider only undirected graphs without loops nor multiple edges. We will use nğ‘›n and mğ‘šm for denoting the number of vertices and edges, respectively, of the input graph of the problem under consideration.
We denote by uâ€‹vğ‘¢ğ‘£uv an edge between vertices uğ‘¢u and vğ‘£v. For a graph GğºG and a vertex setÂ SâŠ†Vâ€‹(G)ğ‘†ğ‘‰ğºS\subseteq V(G), we use the shortcut Gâˆ–Sğºğ‘†G\setminus S to denote Gâ€‹[Vâ€‹(G)âˆ–S]ğºdelimited-[]ğ‘‰ğºğ‘†G[V(G)\setminus S].
The distance between two vertices uğ‘¢u and vğ‘£v in a graph GğºG is the number of edges of a shortest path between uğ‘¢u and vğ‘£v. The diameter of GğºG is the maximum distance over all pairs of vertices of GğºG. For a vertex vğ‘£v inÂ GğºG and a positive integer kğ‘˜k, we denote by Nkâ€‹(v)subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘£N_{k}(v) the set of vertices of GğºG within distance at mostÂ kğ‘˜k from vğ‘£v, and we let Nkâ€‹[v]=Nkâ€‹(v)âˆª{v}subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ‘£subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘£ğ‘£N_{k}[v]=N_{k}(v)\cup\{v\}. We abbreviate N1â€‹(v)subscriptğ‘1ğ‘£N_{1}(v) and N1â€‹[v]subscriptğ‘1delimited-[]ğ‘£N_{1}[v] as Nâ€‹(v)ğ‘ğ‘£N(v) andÂ Nâ€‹[v]ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘£N[v], respectively, and we let dâ€‹(v)=|Nâ€‹(v)|ğ‘‘ğ‘£ğ‘ğ‘£d(v)=|N(v)| be the degree of vğ‘£v in GğºG. A tree is a connected acyclic graph, and a leaf in a tree is a vertex of degree one. For two non-negative integers ağ‘a and bğ‘b, we denote by [a,b]ğ‘ğ‘[a,b] the set containing every integerÂ cğ‘c such that aâ‰¤câ‰¤bğ‘ğ‘ğ‘a\leq c\leq b and we let [a]=[1,a]delimited-[]ğ‘1ğ‘[a]=[1,a]. If a set Sğ‘†S is partitioned into pairwise disjoint sets S1,â€¦,Sksubscriptğ‘†1â€¦subscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜S_{1},\dotsc,S_{k}, we denote it by S=S1âŠâ‹¯âŠSkğ‘†âŠsubscriptğ‘†1â‹¯subscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜S=S_{1}\uplus\dots\uplus S_{k}. Convexity. Activation problems appear in the literature under a number of different names, such as rğ‘Ÿr-neighbor bootstrap percolationÂ         2, dynamic monopoliesÂ  5 8 6 , irreversible conversion  7 3 6, or graph convexities, and were studied by researchers of various fields.
As mentioned in the introduction, in the particular case in which all thresholds are equal to 222, generalized TSS model is also called 222-neighbor bootstrap percolation or P3subscriptğ‘ƒ3P_{3}-convexity, which is studied in the field of graph convexities. A finite graph convexityÂ 7 is a pair (G,ğ’)ğºğ’(G,\mathcal{C}) consisting of a finite simple graphÂ G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) and a set ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} of subsets of Vğ‘‰V (called convex sets) satisfying thatÂ âˆ…,Vâˆˆğ’ğ‘‰ğ’\emptyset,V\in\mathcal{C} and that if C1,C2âˆˆğ’subscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶2ğ’C_{1},C_{2}\in\mathcal{C}, then C1âˆ©C2âˆˆğ’subscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶2ğ’C_{1}\cap C_{2}\in\mathcal{C}. In words, âˆ…\emptyset and Vğ‘‰V are convex sets and the intersection of convex sets is a convex set. The convex hullÂ Hğ’â€‹(S)subscriptğ»ğ’ğ‘†H_{\mathcal{C}}(S) of a set Sğ‘†S is the minimum convex set containing Sğ‘†S, that is,Â Hğ’â€‹(S)subscriptğ»ğ’ğ‘†H_{\mathcal{C}}(S) is the intersection of all convex sets containing Sğ‘†S. When Hğ’â€‹(S)=Vsubscriptğ»ğ’ğ‘†ğ‘‰H_{\mathcal{C}}(S)=V then Sğ‘†S is a hull set of GğºG.
Some well-studied graph convexities are the so-called path convexities, such as the P3subscriptğ‘ƒ3P_{3}-convexityÂ 7, geodesic convexityÂ 8, and monophonic convexityÂ 3. In the following, we show that instances of the generalized TSS model
induce graph convexities in most cases. Let (G,Ï„)ğºğœ(G,\tau) be an instance of the generalized TSS model, whereÂ G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) is a graph and Ï„:Vâ†’â„•:ğœâ†’ğ‘‰â„•\tau:V\to\mathbb{N} is a generalized threshold function. For every set SâŠ†Vğ‘†ğ‘‰S\subseteq V, let the interval IÏ„â€‹(S)âŠ‡Sğ‘†subscriptğ¼ğœğ‘†I_{\tau}(S)\supseteq S be the union of the set Sğ‘†S with the set of all vertices vğ‘£v outside Sğ‘†S which have Ï„â€‹(v)ğœğ‘£\tau(v) neighbors in Sğ‘†S. From this, let ğ’Ï„subscriptğ’ğœ\mathcal{C_{\tau}} be the family of subsets Sğ‘†S of Vğ‘‰V such thatÂ IÏ„â€‹(S)=Ssubscriptğ¼ğœğ‘†ğ‘†I_{\tau}(S)=S (that is, no vertex vğ‘£v outsideÂ Sğ‘†S has Ï„â€‹(v)ğœğ‘£\tau(v) neighbors in Sğ‘†S). Given an instance (G,Ï„)ğºğœ(G,\tau) of the generalized TSS model, where G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) is a graph andÂ Ï„:Vâ†’â„•:ğœâ†’ğ‘‰â„•\tau:V\to\mathbb{N} is a generalized threshold function in GğºG, the pair (G,ğ’Ï„)ğºsubscriptğ’ğœ(G,\mathcal{C}_{\tau}) is a graph convexity if and only if V=âˆ…ğ‘‰V=\emptyset or all thresholds are strictly positive. We have to prove that âˆ…,Vâˆˆğ’Ï„ğ‘‰subscriptğ’ğœ\emptyset,V\in\mathcal{C}_{\tau} and that if C1,C2âˆˆğ’Ï„subscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶2subscriptğ’ğœC_{1},C_{2}\in\mathcal{C}_{\tau}, then C1âˆ©C2âˆˆğ’Ï„subscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶2subscriptğ’ğœC_{1}\cap C_{2}\in\mathcal{C}_{\tau}. ClearlyÂ Vâˆˆğ’Ï„ğ‘‰subscriptğ’ğœV\in\mathcal{C}_{\tau} by vacuity, since there is no vertex outside Vğ‘‰V.
Thus, if V=âˆ…ğ‘‰V=\emptyset, (G,ğ’Ï„)ğºsubscriptğ’ğœ(G,\mathcal{C}_{\tau}) is a graph convexity, since the only subsetÂ Sğ‘†S of Vğ‘‰V is S=âˆ…=Vğ‘†ğ‘‰S=\emptyset=V. So assume that Vâ‰ âˆ…ğ‘‰V\neq\emptyset. First consider that there is a vertex vğ‘£v with threshold Ï„â€‹(v)=0ğœğ‘£0\tau(v)=0.
With this, we have thatÂ S=âˆ…ğ‘†S=\emptyset is not convex, since vâˆ‰S=âˆ…ğ‘£ğ‘†v\not\in S=\emptyset and vğ‘£v has Ï„â€‹(v)=0ğœğ‘£0\tau(v)=0 neighbors in S=âˆ…ğ‘†S=\emptyset. ThenÂ (G,ğ’Ï„)ğºsubscriptğ’ğœ(G,\mathcal{C}_{\tau}) is not a graph convexity. Now assume that all thresholds are strictly positive.
Therefore S=âˆ…ğ‘†S=\emptyset is convex, since any vertex vğ‘£v does not have Ï„â€‹(v)ğœğ‘£\tau(v) neighbors in S=âˆ…ğ‘†S=\emptyset. Finally, consider two sets S1,S2âˆˆğ’Ï„subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘†2subscriptğ’ğœS_{1},S_{2}\in\mathcal{C}_{\tau} and let S=S1âˆ©S2ğ‘†subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘†2S=S_{1}\cap S_{2}. If S1=Vsubscriptğ‘†1ğ‘‰S_{1}=V or S2=Vsubscriptğ‘†2ğ‘‰S_{2}=V, then S=S2ğ‘†subscriptğ‘†2S=S_{2} or S=S1ğ‘†subscriptğ‘†1S=S_{1}, respectively, and henceÂ Sâˆˆğ’Ï„ğ‘†subscriptğ’ğœS\in\mathcal{C}_{\tau}. So assume that S1â‰ Vsubscriptğ‘†1ğ‘‰S_{1}\neq V and S2â‰ Vsubscriptğ‘†2ğ‘‰S_{2}\neq V, and letÂ vâˆˆVâˆ–Sğ‘£ğ‘‰ğ‘†v\in V\setminus S. Then vâˆ‰S1ğ‘£subscriptğ‘†1v\not\in S_{1} orÂ vâˆ‰S2ğ‘£subscriptğ‘†2v\not\in S_{2}. ConsiderÂ vâˆ‰S1ğ‘£subscriptğ‘†1v\not\in S_{1}. Since S1âˆˆğ’Ï„subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ’ğœS_{1}\in\mathcal{C}_{\tau}, vğ‘£v does not have Ï„â€‹(v)ğœğ‘£\tau(v) neighbors inÂ S1subscriptğ‘†1S_{1} and consequently does not have Ï„â€‹(v)ğœğ‘£\tau(v) neighbors in Sğ‘†S. The case vâˆ‰S2ğ‘£subscriptğ‘†2v\not\in S_{2} is analogous. ThenÂ S=S1âˆ©S2âŠ†ğ’Ï„ğ‘†subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘†2subscriptğ’ğœS=S_{1}\cap S_{2}\subseteq\mathcal{C}_{\tau}. In this context, we can also define the activation time tÏ„â€‹(S)subscriptğ‘¡ğœğ‘†t_{\tau}(S) of a vertex subsetÂ Sğ‘†S (not necessarily a target set) as the minimum tğ‘¡t such that IÏ„t+1â€‹(S)=IÏ„tâ€‹(S)superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğœğ‘¡1ğ‘†superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğœğ‘¡ğ‘†I_{\tau}^{t+1}(S)=I_{\tau}^{t}(S), where IÏ„kâ€‹(S)superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğœğ‘˜ğ‘†I_{\tau}^{k}(S) is the kğ‘˜k-th iterate of the interval function, defined recursively as IÏ„0â€‹(S)=Ssuperscriptsubscriptğ¼ğœ0ğ‘†ğ‘†I_{\tau}^{0}(S)=S and IÏ„kâ€‹(S)=IÏ„kâˆ’1â€‹(IÏ„â€‹(S))superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğœğ‘˜ğ‘†superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğœğ‘˜1subscriptğ¼ğœğ‘†I_{\tau}^{k}(S)=I_{\tau}^{k-1}(I_{\tau}(S)) forÂ kâ‰¥1ğ‘˜1k\geq 1. We can also define HÏ„â€‹(S)subscriptğ»ğœğ‘†H_{\tau}(S) as HÏ„â€‹(S)=IÏ„tÏ„â€‹(S)â€‹(S)subscriptğ»ğœğ‘†superscriptsubscriptğ¼ğœsubscriptğ‘¡ğœğ‘†ğ‘†H_{\tau}(S)=I_{\tau}^{t_{\tau}(S)}(S). This definition of HÏ„â€‹(S)subscriptğ»ğœğ‘†H_{\tau}(S) is useful even when (G,ğ’Ï„)ğºsubscriptğ’ğœ(G,\mathcal{C}_{\tau}) is not a graph convexity (for example, when some thresholds are 0). Recall that a vertex subset Sğ‘†S is a target set ifÂ HÏ„â€‹(S)=Vsubscriptğ»ğœğ‘†ğ‘‰H_{\tau}(S)=V. In this paper, we will use these notations IÏ„â€‹(S)subscriptğ¼ğœğ‘†I_{\tau}(S) and HÏ„â€‹(S)subscriptğ»ğœğ‘†H_{\tau}(S). When Ï„ğœ\tau is clear in the context, the subscript will be removed from the notations Iâ€‹(S)ğ¼ğ‘†I(S) and Hâ€‹(S)ğ»ğ‘†H(S). The study of complexity aspects related to the computation of graph convexity parameters have been the main goal of various recent papersÂ 1   6 9 .
From LemmaÂ 2.1, all known convexity parameters, such as the CarathÃ©odory number, the Radon number, the Helly number and the convexity numberÂ 1 are meaningful in the TSS model and can be investigated in this context. Parameterized complexity. We refer the reader toÂ 2 8 for basic background on parameterized complexity, and we recall here only the definitions used in this article. A parameterized problem is a language LâŠ†Î£âˆ—Ã—â„•ğ¿superscriptÎ£â„•L\subseteq\Sigma^{*}\times\mathbb{N}. For an instance I=(x,k)âˆˆÎ£âˆ—Ã—â„•ğ¼ğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptÎ£â„•I=(x,k)\in\Sigma^{*}\times\mathbb{N}, kğ‘˜k is called the parameter. A parameterized problem Lğ¿L is fixed-parameter tractable (FPT) if there exists an algorithmÂ ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}, a computable function fğ‘“f, and a constant cğ‘c such that given an instance I=(x,k)ğ¼ğ‘¥ğ‘˜I=(x,k),Â ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} (called an FPT algorithm) correctly decides whether IâˆˆLğ¼ğ¿I\in L in time bounded by fâ€‹(k)â‹…|I|câ‹…ğ‘“ğ‘˜superscriptğ¼ğ‘f(k)\cdot|I|^{c}. Within parameterized problems, the class \W may be seen as the parameterized equivalent to the class \NPÂ of classical decision problems. Without entering into details (seeÂ 2 8 for the formal definitions), a parameterized problem being \W-hard can be seen as a strong evidence that this problem is not FPT. Minors, treewidth, and bounded local treewidth. A graph Hğ»H is a minor of a graphÂ GğºG if Hğ»H can be obtained from a subgraph of GğºG by contracting edges. A graph class ğ’ğ’{\cal C} is minor-closed if whenever a graph GğºG belongs to ğ’ğ’{\cal C}, all its minors belong to ğ’ğ’{\cal C} as well. A graph is planar if it can be drawn in the plane so that its edges may intersect only in the extremities. A graph GğºG is an apex graph if it contains a vertex whose removal from GğºG results in a planar graph. Let kâ‰¥0ğ‘˜0k\geq 0 be an integer. A graph GğºG is a kğ‘˜k-tree if GğºG can be obtained from a clique of sizeÂ k+1ğ‘˜1k+1 by repeatedly adding vertices adjacent to a clique of size kğ‘˜k of the current graph. The treewidth of a graph GğºG, denoted by ğ—ğ—â€‹(G)ğ—ğ—ğº{\sf tw}(G), is the smallest integer kğ‘˜k such that GğºG is a subgraph of a kğ‘˜k-tree. A graph class ğ’ğ’{\cal C} has bounded local treewidth if there exists a function f:â„•â†’â„•:ğ‘“â†’â„•â„•f:\mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{N} such that, for every graph Gâˆˆğ’ğºğ’G\in{\cal C}, every vertex vâˆˆVâ€‹(G)ğ‘£ğ‘‰ğºv\in V(G), and every positive integer kğ‘˜k, ğ—ğ—â€‹(Gâ€‹[Nkâ€‹[v]])â‰¤fâ€‹(k)ğ—ğ—ğºdelimited-[]subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ‘£ğ‘“ğ‘˜{\sf tw}(G[N_{k}[v]])\leq f(k). Examples of graph classes of bounded local treewidth are graphs of bounded treewidth, graphs of bounded degree, planar graphs, or graphs of bounded genus; seeÂ 9 for more on bounded local treewidth. The following theorem of EppsteinÂ 6 states that, for minor-closed graph classes, having bounded local treewidth is equivalent to excluding some apex graph. Let ğ’ğ’{\cal C} be a minor-closed graph class. Then ğ’ğ’{\cal C} has bounded local treewidth if and only if ğ’ğ’{\cal C} does not contain all apex graphs. Monadic second-order logic of graphs. The syntax of monadic second-order logic (ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–®ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–®{\sf MSO}) of graphs includes the logical connectives âˆ¨\vee, âˆ§\wedge, Â¬\neg, variables for vertices, edges, sets of vertices and sets of edges, the quantifiers âˆ€,âˆƒfor-all\forall,\exists that can be applied to these variables, and the binary relations expressing whether a vertex or an edge belong to a set, whether an edge is incident to vertex, whether two vertices are adjacent, and whether two sets are equal. ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–®1subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–®1{\sf MSO}_{1} is the restriction of ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–®ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–®{\sf MSO} where only quantification over sets of vertices (but not edges) is allowed.
The following result of CourcelleÂ 7
is one of the most widely used results in the area of parameterized complexity. Checking whether an ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–®ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–®{\sf MSO} formula Ï•italic-Ï•\phi holds on an nğ‘›n-vertex graph of treewidth at most ğ—ğ—ğ—ğ—{\sf tw} can be done in time gâ€‹(Ï•,ğ—ğ—)â‹…nâ‹…ğ‘”italic-Ï•ğ—ğ—ğ‘›g(\phi,{\sf tw})\cdot n, for a computable function gğ‘”g.
